What_Are_the_Pros_and_Cons.head: What Are the Pros and Cons of Refinancing Your Home?
What_Are_the_Pros_and_Cons.sub: The financial market sometimes refers to a home mortgage as “good debt.” This is largely because unlike a credit card or personal loan, a mortgage can help you buy and own an asset that may increase in value as time goes on.

What_Veterans_Should.head: What Veterans Should Know
What_Veterans_Should.sub: FHA and VA loans are both government-backed loans that can be great options for first-time homebuyers, with each having similarities and differences in terms of requirements. In this guide, we'll break down the specific qualifications needed for each loan so you can determine which one is right for you when buying a house.

Comparing_FHA_and_Conventional.head: Comparing FHA and Conventional Home Loans
Comparing_FHA_and_Conventional.sub: When it comes to mortgages, you have a lot of options. Two of the most common are FHA and conventional loans. Though both can be great products to help you buy a home, each has its own unique pros and cons.

FHA_Loan_Refinancing.head: FHA Loan Refinancing Options
FHA_Loan_Refinancing.sub: Refinancing can be an excellent way to lower your monthly payment, shorten your loan term, change loan products or even get cash from your home.

fhaLoan.head: FHA Loan Program
fhaLoan.sub_1: Complete Guide to the FHA Loan
fhaLoan.sub_2: In this comprehensive guide to Federal Housing Administration loans, or FHA loans, we will cover:

section_1.head: SECTION 1
section_1.txt_1: An FHA loan is a mortgage loan option for U.S. home buyers. It is guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration, an agency of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and issued by FHA-approved lenders across the country.
section_1.txt_2: FHA loans are well known for their affordability - namely their 3.5% percent down payment and relatively lenient credit requirements. According to HUD, the FHA has insured more than 47 million mortgage loans since its inception in 1934.

section_2.head: SECTION 2
section_2.txt_1: There are more than a dozen FHA mortgage programs, with each varying slightly in structure and use. The most common FHA loan types are:
section_2.txt_3: Fixed-rate mortgages are the most common type of FHA loan, as they offer a reliable, consistent payment that homeowners can count on. These typically come in 15- and 30-year terms and have the same interest rate for the entirety of that term. While the government fully backs the loan, lenders set their own interest rates.
section_2.txt_5: Adjustable-rate FHA loans have interest rates that vary over time. They may have a period of 3, 5 or 7 years in which the initial low rate is fixed, but after that period lapses, the rate can rise. This means your mortgage payment would rise as well.
section_2.txt_7: FHA Energy Efficient Mortgages, or EEMs, encourage homeowners to make energy-efficient upgrades on their properties. The loans can be used to cover the costs of acceptable energy-related improvements on an existing home or a new home you're purchasing.
section_2.txt_9: There are other, less-used FHA loan types as well, including the 203(k) - a mortgage generally reserved for fixed-uppers. The FHA 203(k) loan allows you to roll the costs of your repair and renovation expenses into your mortgage, which is based on the expected higher value of the property after those improvements are made.
section_2.txt_10: There are also streamline refinance FHA loans, which offer existing FHA borrowers a quick and easy refinancing process, as well as Title 1 FHA loans that cover home improvements and repairs.

section_3.head: SECTION 3
section_3.txt_1: Your FHA loan eligibility depends on your credit score, income, debts, home price and the size of your down payment, as well as various other factors.
section_3.txt_3: To qualify for an FHA loan, you'll need sufficient credit and income to show lenders you have an ability and willingness to repay the debt.
section_3.txt_5: Have a valid Social Security number
section_3.txt_7: Make a down payment of at least 3.5 percent
section_3.txt_8: Intend to use the property as your primary residence
section_3.txt_9: Have an appraisal performed on the property by an approved appraiser
section_3.txt_11: To take advantage of the FHA loan's 3.5 percent down payment, you'll need a credit score of at least 580. Borrowers with credit scores below 580 may be able to qualify with a 10 percent down payment. But it's also important to understand that FHA lenders can have credit score minimums that exceed what the government requires.
section_3.txt_12: If you've filed for bankruptcy, you'll need to be at least two years removed from the filing and have since established good credit. If you've experienced a foreclosure, you must be three years removed for the foreclosure.
section_3.txt_13: Guidelines and policies on credit can vary by lender.
section_3.txt_15: Lenders will look at the relationship between your gross monthly income and your major monthly debts when evaluating your loan file. Guidelines and restrictions on debt-to-income (DTI) ratio can vary by lender and other factors.
section_3.txt_16: Some lenders may have lower thresholds than others, and borrowers with more challenging loan files can encounter more restrictive DTI guidelines.
section_3.txt_17: Unlike USDA loans, FHA loans do not have restrictions on how much income borrowers can make.
section_3.txt_19: In order to protect homeowners as well as their financial investment, the FHA also sets requirements for what types of properties can be financed with FHA funding. To determine if your home meets these minimum requirements, your lender will order an appraisal of the property.
section_3.txt_20: The appraiser will evaluate the condition of:
section_3.txt_21: Have a valid Social Security number
section_3.txt_22: Each area and room on the property, including any attics or basements
section_3.txt_29: They'll specifically be looking for signs of damage, deferred maintenance or deterioration. Normal wear and tear will be noted, but as long as a property appears well-maintained, it should qualify for FHA financing.
section_3.txt_30: The main goals of the FHA appraisal: 1) Ensure the home is a healthy, safe and structurally sound building to live in and 2) Make sure the actual value of the home matches or exceeds the purchase price.
section_3.txt_31: In the event the home doesn't pass appraisal or repairs are required, the seller will need to make the repairs. If the home doesn't appraise for at least the purchase price, buyers can talk with the seller about renegotiating in light of the low valuation.

section_4.head: SECTION 4
section_4.txt_1: Thanks to their relaxed credit and debt-to-income requirements, FHA loans are largely considered one of the easiest mortgage products to qualify for. They also require minimal down payments, making them ideal for borrowers without a lot of savings.
section_4.txt_3: "The FHA loan is particularly popular with first-time home buyers, largely because of its low down payment requirements."
section_4.txt_6: FHA loans come with low credit score requirements when compared to other loan options, requiring a minimum of just 500. Typically, conventional loans requires a score of 620, while USDA loans require a 600 or higher.
section_4.txt_7: Credit score benchmarks for FHA loans will vary lender.
section_4.txt_9: Adjustable-rate FHA loans have interest rates that vary over time. They may have a period of 3, 5 or 7 years in which the initial low rate is fixed, but after that period lapses, the rate can rise. This means your mortgage payment would rise as well.
section_4.txt_11: One of the biggest benefits of the FHA loan is its low down payment requirements. If you have a 580 credit score or higher, you can put down just 3.5 percent, compared to the typical 5 percent you'll need for conventional financing.
section_4.txt_12: FHA loans also allow you to use qualified gift funds toward your down payment or closing costs. Talk with lenders about their policies and required documentation regarding gift funds.
section_4.txt_14: FHA loans can be used on a variety of property types, including single-family homes, condo units, duplexes, manufactured housing and mobile homes.
section_4.txt_16: Get a quote for a low money down FHA Home Loan →
section_4.txt_18: The FHA loan is particularly popular with first-time home buyers, largely because of its low down payment requirements. Their more lenient credit standards are also helpful to first-timers, who many times are lacking a robust credit history.
section_4.txt_19: Other loan types may prove more difficult for new home buyers, simply due to more stringent credit, income and down payment requirements. Many first-time buyers don't have deep savings accounts or the ability to make a sizable down payment. FHA loans offer an affordable, hassle-free route toward home ownership for these cash-strapped buyers.

section_5.head: SECTION 5
section_5.txt_1: While this is a government-backed loan, there is not a set interest rate for FHA loans. FHA lenders set and quote their own interest rates. Rates can vary depending on the lender, the loan type, the borrower's credit score and more.
section_5.txt_2: Fixed interest rates on FHA loans tend to be slightly lower than those on conventional mortgage programs, simply because lenders have more protection. They have the added insurance of FHA's backing, which allows them to take extra risk and offer lower rates.
section_5.txt_4: Check Out Today's FHA loan rates

section_6.head: SECTION 6
section_6.txt_1: In order to allow for such low down payments and credit scores, the FHA does require you pay a Mortgage Insurance Premium (MIP) to protect the agency in case you default. You'll pay this once as an upfront fee at closing and then again month after month, along with your mortgage payment.
section_6.txt_3: This is a one-time MIP payment you'll make at closing. It costs 1.75 percent of your total home loan balance (not the home's price), regardless of your credit score or debt-to-income ratio.
section_6.txt_5: Your annual MIP payments will be calculated every year and built into your monthly mortgage payments. The total of these payments will depend on your loan-to-value ratio, your loan balance and your loan's term.
section_6.txt_6: Here's an example: If you had a 30-year loan of $200,000 and an loan-to-value ratio of 90 percent, your annual MIP would be $1,600. Spread out over 12 months, that would mean about $133 paid in MIP every month.
section_6.txt_8: You may not have to pay your annual MIP forever. Depending on your loan term, your loan-to-value ratio and when your loan was originated, you may be able to cancel your MIP and subsequently lower your monthly payment.
section_6.txt_9: For loans originated before June 3, 2013, MIP durations are as follows:
section_6.txt_10: On FHA loans originated after June 3, 2013, annual MIP durations look like this:

table_2.r4_c3: Cancelled at 78 percent LTV (5 years minimum)

section_7.head: SECTION 7
section_7.txt_1: Limits on FHA loans vary by location and property type. They amount to 115 percent of the county's median home price, so they fluctuate every year as the local market changes. You can find your FHA loan limits using this tool at HUD.gov.
section_7.txt_2: FHA lenders also offers jumbo loans, meaning loans in excess of the FHA limit for your area. For jumbo FHA loans, lenders may have tighter guidelines for minimum credit score, credit history, DTI ratio and more.
section_7.txt_3: Check Loan Limits In Your Area
section_7.txt_4: Use our FHA Loan Limit Calculator to see what you may qualify for.

section_8.head: SECTION 8
section_8.txt_1: All mortgage loans come with certain closing costs, which can vary from lender to lender. On FHA loans, closing costs tend to equal around 2 to 5 percent of the total loan amount. Just a few of the closing costs you may need to pay on your FHA loan include an origination fee, survey, appraisal, underwriting fee and more.
section_8.txt_2: As the buyer, you are responsible for covering closing costs, but with an FHA loan, you can ask the seller to contribute a portion of them. These are called concessions, and sellers can put up to 6 percent of the home's total sales price toward your closing costs. Sellers cannot contribute toward your down payment requirement.

section_9.head: SECTION 9
section_9.txt_1: If you already have a home loan, you can opt to use an FHA mortgage when refinancing your existing loan. You might do this if mortgage rates fall below your current loan's rate or if the fixed period of your adjustable-rate loan is ending.
section_9.txt_3: If you have an FHA loan and want to refinance to a new one, it's called a streamline refinance. To qualify, you need to have made at least six payments on your current loan and your closing date must be at least 210 days past.
section_9.txt_5: If you have a conventional loan, refinancing to an FHA mortgage can have big benefits. You can refinance up to 96.5 percent of your current home value using an FHA refinance.
section_9.txt_7: Find Out How Much an FHA Refinance Can Save You! →
section_9.txt_9: In order to refinance an existing FHA loan, you need to see “net tangible benefit” from the transaction. This simply means that the refinance improves your financial position in one of the following ways:
section_9.txt_10: The principal loan balance and interest is reduced by at least 5 percent.
section_9.txt_11: The new adjustable rate is 2 percent lower than your current fixed rate.
section_9.txt_12: The new fixed rate is less than 2 percent higher than your current adjustable rate.
section_9.txt_13: The term of the loan has been reduced.
section_9.txt_15: If you've owned your home for a while and need to pay for home repairs, college tuition, debts or just need extra funds, then a cash-out FHA refinance offers a solution. Using these loans, qualified buyers can look to refinance up to 85 percent of the home's value.

section_10.head: SECTION 10
section_10.sub: How to Apply for an FHA Loan
section_10.txt_1: The first step is to find a lender approved by the FHA. You can use
section_10.txt_3: tool to find one in your area.
section_10.txt_5: Talk with a loan specialist about getting preapproved. This will tell you if you meet the minimum eligibility requirements for an FHA loan and the maximum loan you can apply for.
section_10.txt_6: Find your property and sign a purchase agreement with the seller.
section_10.txt_7: Finalize your loan application with your lender.
section_10.txt_8: Await your appraisal. The lender will order an appraisal of the property to ensure it meets FHA standards.
section_10.txt_9: Wait as your loan is underwritten and processed by the lender.
section_10.txt_10: Attend closing, This is when you'll sign your papers, pay your closing costs and get your keys.
section_10.txt_12: Make sure you stay in touch with your loan officer throughout the process, as they may need additional documentation along the way. The more responsive you are, the better. Any missing paperwork would delay your closing and your move onto the property.
section_10.txt_13: See if you qualify for a Low Money Down FHA Home Loan

vaLoan.head: VA Loan Program
vaLoan.sub_1: Complete Guide to the VA Loan
vaLoan.sub_2: Your Complete Guide to the VA Home Loan

section_1.head: SECTION 1
section_1.txt_1: The VA loan is a $0 down mortgage option available to Veterans, Service Members and select military spouses. VA loans are issued by private lenders, such as a mortgage company or bank, and guaranteed by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).
section_1.txt_2: The VA home loan was created in 1944 by the United States government to help returning service members purchase homes without needing a down payment or excellent credit. This historic program has guaranteed more than 25 million VA loans, helping Veterans, active duty military members and their families purchase or refinance a home.
section_1.txt_3: Today, the VA mortgage is more important than ever. Scores of Veteran and military buyers found it increasingly difficult to get home financing in the wake of the Great Recession, and many lenders tightened their guidelines again because of the 2020 global pandemic.
section_1.txt_4: Over the last decade in particular, VA loans have provided a lifeline for Veterans and active Military homebuyers facing higher credit score and down payment requirements.
section_1.txt_5: VA loans are a specialized loan product, but they aren't more difficult or cumbersome than other types of home loans. This VA loan guide is here to provide you with the tools necessary to navigate your VA home purchase or refinance and get the most out of your hard-earned benefit.

section_2.head: SECTION 2
section_2.sub: Am I Eligibility for a VA Loan
section_2.txt_1: To be eligible for a VA loan, you or your spouse must meet the minimum service requirements set by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), have a valid Certificate of Eligibility (COE) and satisfy the lender's credit and income requirements.
section_2.txt_2: Who is Eligible for a VA Loan?
section_2.txt_3: You may be eligible for a VA loan by meeting one or more of the following requirements:
section_2.txt_4: You served 90 consecutive days of active service during wartime.
section_2.txt_5: You served 181 days of active service during peacetime.
section_2.txt_6: You have 6 years of service in the National Guard or Reserves.
section_2.txt_7: You are the spouse of a service member who has died in the line of duty or as a result of a service-related disability.
section_2.txt_8: If you don't meet the basic service requirements for a VA loan, you may still be eligible. In these cases, eligibility depends on the discharge type. If your discharge falls into any of the following categories, you might still qualify for a VA loan:
section_2.txt_9: You were discharged for hardship, or at the convenience of the government, or a reduction in force.
section_2.txt_10: You were discharged for a medical condition or service-connected disability.
section_2.txt_11: You were discharged for early-out and served at least 21 months of a 2-year enlistment.

section_3.head: SECTION 3
section_3.txt_1: VA loans are one of the most powerful mortgage options on the market for Veterans, active military and surviving spouses.
section_3.txt_2: The power behind the VA loan comes from a handful of significant financial benefits not typically found in other mortgage types. These advantages compared to different loan options are a big reason why VA loan volume has grown considerably over the last 15 years.
section_3.txt_3: This historic benefit program has helped millions of Veterans, service members and military families achieve the dream of homeownership. As a result, VA loan use has soared since the Great Recession, and these government-backed loans are arguably one of the best mortgage products on the market today.
section_3.txt_4: Let's take a deeper look at the most significant VA loan advantages.
section_3.txt_6: VA purchase loans increased for the ninth straight year in fiscal year 2020, according to the Department of Veterans Affairs.
section_3.txt_7: Start your VA Loan quote online
section_3.txt_9: By far, the single-largest benefit of the VA loan is that qualified Veterans can purchase without a down payment. This huge advantage allows Veterans and service members to buy homes without having to spend years saving for that typical lump-sum payment.
section_3.txt_10: The minimum down payment amount on an FHA loan is 3.5 percent, and for conventional financing, it's often 5 percent. On a $250,000 mortgage, a military borrower would need to come up with $8,700 in cash for an FHA loan and $12,500 for a typical conventional loan. Those can be significant sums of cash for the average military borrower.
section_3.txt_11: Saving money and building credit can be difficult for service members who are constantly on the move. With the VA loan, qualified borrowers can finance 100 percent of the home's value without putting down a dime.
section_3.txt_13: Private mortgage insurance (PMI) is insurance that protects lenders in case of a borrower default. Many conventional lenders require borrowers to pay private monthly mortgage insurance unless they can put down at least 20 percent, which is challenging for many Veterans. Conventional borrowers will need to pay this monthly fee until they build 20 percent equity in the home.
section_3.txt_14: FHA loans feature their own form of monthly mortgage insurance.
section_3.txt_15: Unlike conventional and FHA loans, VA loans don't require monthly mortgage insurance. No private mortgage insurance means Veterans who secured a VA loan last year will save billions in mortgage insurance costs over the life of their loans.
section_3.txt_16: No PMI allows Veterans to stretch their buying power and save.
section_3.txt_18: Here's another big way the VA loan program saves Veterans money: Having the lowest average fixed rates on the market.
section_3.txt_19: VA loans have had the lowest average 30-year fixed rate on the market for the last six years, according to data from ICE Mortgage Technology.
section_3.txt_20: VA interest rates are typically 0.5 to 1 percent lower than conventional interest rates. Lower rates help Veterans save every month and over the life of their loan.
section_3.txt_22: Since the Department of Veterans Affairs only oversees the loan program and does not issue loans, the agency does not set or enforce credit score minimums. However, most VA lenders use credit score benchmarks to help assess a borrower's risk of default.
section_3.txt_23: Credit score cutoffs can vary, but the minimums are typically lower than what borrowers need for conventional mortgages.
section_3.txt_24: Veterans don't need anything near perfect credit to secure home financing at competitive interest rates. VA loans are also more forgiving when bouncing back after a bankruptcy, foreclosure or short sale.
section_3.txt_26: All mortgages come with fees and closing costs, but the VA actually limits what Veterans can be charged when it comes to these expenses. In fact, some costs and fees must be covered by other parties in the transaction. These safeguards help make homeownership affordable for qualified homebuyers.
section_3.txt_27: VA borrowers can ask a seller to pay all of their loan-related closing costs and up to 4 percent in concessions, which can cover things like prepaid taxes and insurance, paying off collections and judgments and more.
section_3.txt_28: There's no guarantee the seller will agree to that request, but Veterans can certainly ask during the negotiation process.
section_3.txt_30: One of the most common misconceptions about the VA mortgage program is that it's a one-time benefit.
section_3.txt_31: Veterans who qualify for a VA loan can use this program over and over again, and the benefit never expires. Unlike what you may have heard, you don't necessarily have to pay back your VA loan in full to use your benefit again.
section_3.txt_32: It's even possible to have more than one VA loan at the same time with second-tier entitlement.
section_3.txt_33: Don't think that using your home loan benefit decades ago means you're no longer eligible or that because you have a VA mortgage at your current duty station means you can't purchase again with a VA loan when you PCS across the country.
section_3.txt_35: With some types of loans, paying off a home loan before it matures results in a pre-payment penalty. This is because lenders miss out on additional opportunities to collect interest payments. The prepayment penalty is a way for financial institutions to recoup some of that money.
section_3.txt_36: The VA loan allows borrowers to pay off their home loan at any point without having to worry about a prepayment penalty. Borrowers are free to consider future home purchases and refinancing options with the absence of a prepayment penalty.

section_4.head: SECTION 4
section_4.txt_1: Because the federal government backs VA home loans, lenders have the luxury of charging competitively low interest rates. Eligible veterans and service members find that rates are generally lower with a VA home loan than a conventional mortgage.
section_4.txt_2: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) doesn't set interest rates. Your lender determines the rate on your VA loan based on your unique financial situation.
section_4.txt_3: Common Questions about VA Loan Rates
section_4.txt_4: Getting a mortgage can be complicated. Veterans United works to simplify the process through education and helping you understand your options.
section_4.txt_5: We've compiled some of the most common mortgage rate questions below so that you can make more informed decisions.
section_4.txt_7: Private lenders, such as mortgage companies and banks, set interest rates on VA loans. The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) does not set the rate but backs a portion of each loan against default.
section_4.txt_8: How do VA loan rates compare with the rest of the market?
section_4.txt_9: On average, VA loan rates are typically lower than both FHA and conventional mortgage rates. VA loan rates are generally lower due to the VA backing a portion of each loan.

section_5.head: SECTION 5
section_5.txt_1: The VA Home Loan program provides qualified homeowners with a simple way to take advantage of lower rates and decrease their monthly mortgage payment. Beyond that, military homeowners can get cash back on a VA refinance and use the proceeds for a variety of needs, from paying off debt or making home improvements and much more. The current economic climate makes now a great time or many military homeowners to take advantage of the numerous benefits found in a VA refinance.
section_5.txt_2: Two main programs help VA borrowers refinance to a lower rate -- the VA Streamline Refinance, also known as the Interest Rate Reduction Refinance Loan (IRRRL), and the VA Cash-Out Refinance.
section_5.txt_4: Eligibility for a VA Refinance is similar to that of a home purchase VA Loan.
section_5.txt_5: Typically, you can qualify if you served on active duty for more than 90 consecutive days during wartime or more than 181 days of service during peacetime.
section_5.txt_6: For National Guard members and Reservists, the veteran must have served at least six years.
section_5.txt_7: Some surviving spouses of veterans who died while in service or from a service-connected disability may also be eligible.
section_5.txt_8: It is important to note that in order to receive a VA Streamline refinance, you must hold an existing VA Loan.

section_6.head: SECTION 6
section_6.txt_1: The journey to homeownership can oftentimes cause would-be homebuyers to run the gamut of emotions — from excitement to nervousness and everything in between. As the homebuying process transitions and you are under contract, it is important to remember the process is not over and there is still work to be done before celebrating.
section_6.txt_3: Although rare, some homebuyers can lose focus once they are under contract. This can result in some delays to the financing process or even result in losing the opportunity to secure a loan. Your Home Loan Specialist will instruct you on important things to maintain once you are under contract.
section_6.txt_4: Veterans United will review your credit inquiries, bank statements and pay stubs to determine if you have debts that were not disclosed on the application. From the time you apply for the loan to the time you close, we advise you do not apply for any new debts – including co-signing on a note, buying or leasing a vehicle and refinancing other notes - without consulting your loan officer.
section_6.txt_6: Avoid taking on new debt, such as buying a car
section_6.txt_8: Don't move money around or change banks
section_6.txt_9: Keep on top of your bills and don't miss a mortgage payment
section_6.txt_10: Be mindful of credit card limits
section_6.txt_11: Even though your loan may still close, your closing could be delayed while additional documentation is obtained as we work to verify all your information. If the new debt increases your debt load, there is an increased risk of changing your debt to income ratio and effectively ending your chance to purchase the home you have selected.
section_6.txt_12: While this information may cause some trepidation, if you stay on track and follow the guidance of your Home Loan Specialist, you have little to worry about. If you have any questions about these possible hiccups, please do not hesitate to contact your dedicated VA Loan specialist.

fmLoan.head: Fannie Mae
fmLoan.sub_1: Loans, HomePath, and All You Should Know
fmLoan.sub_2: Your Complete Guide to the Fannie Mae

section_1.head: SECTION 1
section_1.txt_1: Fannie Mae—known officially as the Federal National Mortgage Association (FNMA)—is a government-sponsored enterprise (GSE) chartered by Congress to stimulate homeownership and provide liquidity to the mortgage market.1 It was established in 1938 during the Great Depression as part of the New Deal. Its purpose is to help low- to moderate-income borrowers obtain financing for a home.
section_1.txt_3: Fannie Mae is a government-sponsored enterprise (GSE) created by Congress.
section_1.txt_4: Fannie Mae doesn't originate or give out mortgages to homeowners looking for funding, but it does buy and guarantee mortgages through the secondary mortgage market.
section_1.txt_5: By investing in mortgages, Fannie Mae creates more liquidity for lenders, including banks, thrifts, and credit unions, which then allows them to underwrite or fund more mortgages.
section_1.txt_6: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac nearly collapsed amid the 2008 financial crisis, but were bailed out and placed into government conservatorship; eventually, they paid back the billions of dollars that they had received to survive.

section_2.head: SECTION 2
section_2.txt_1: As a secondary mortgage market participant, Fannie Mae does not originate mortgage loans. Instead, it keeps funds flowing to lenders by purchasing or guaranteeing mortgages issued by credit unions, banks, thrifts, and other financial institutions. It is one of two large purchasers of mortgages in the secondary market. The other is its sibling Freddie Mac, or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, which is also a GSE chartered by Congress.
section_2.txt_2: After purchasing mortgages on the secondary market, Fannie Mae can pool them to form a mortgage-backed security (MBS). An MBS is an asset-backed security that is secured by a mortgage or pool of mortgages.5 Fannie Mae's mortgage-backed securities are then purchased by institutions, such as insurance companies, pension funds, and investment banks. It guarantees payments of principal and interest on its MBSs.
section_2.txt_3: Fannie Mae also has its own portfolio, commonly referred to as a retained portfolio, which invests in its own and other institutions’ mortgage-backed securities. Fannie Mae issues debt, called agency debt, to fund its retained portfolio.
section_2.txt_4: By investing in the mortgage market, Fannie Mae creates liquidity for lenders, which in turn allows them to underwrite or fund additional mortgages. In 2020, Fannie Mae provided $1.4 trillion in liquidity to the mortgage market, which helped low-income Americans buy, refinance, or rent approximately six million homes.

section_3.head: SECTION 3
section_3.txt_1: To do business with Fannie Mae, a mortgage lender must comply with the Statement on Subprime Lending issued by the federal government. The statement addresses several risks associated with subprime loans, such as low introductory rates followed by a higher variable rate, very high limits on how much an interest rate may increase, limited to no borrower income documentation, and product features that make frequent refinancing of the loan likely.
section_3.txt_2: The mortgages that Fannie Mae purchases and guarantees must meet strict criteria. The limit, for example, for a conventional loan for a single-family home in 2022 is $647,200 (up from $548,250 in 2021) for most areas and $970,800 (up from $822,375 in 2021) for high-cost areas, including Hawaii and Alaska.
section_3.txt_3: To obtain a loan backed by Fannie Mae, you’ll have to go through an approved lender. Along with avoiding subprime loans mentioned above, lenders must meet eligibility and underwriting criteria that ensure the credit quality of the financing.

how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.head: How Fannie Mae’s New Credit Score Rule Can Help You
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_1: Becoming a homeowner is a huge accomplishment and a major milestone for many Americans. Though the home-ownership rate has increased in the past year, there are many individuals impacted by the pandemic who are struggling to reach this goal.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_2: If you are at least a bit familiar with the home buying process, you know that there are many factors that are evaluated when applying for a mortgage loan. Five major factors that determine approval are your credit score, debt-to-income ratio, down payment, work history, and the value and condition of the home. In the past year alone, many Americans lost their jobs during the pandemic, which in some cases affected their credit scores and concurrently their chances of becoming a homeowner. This has especially been the case for couples in which one partner is a very strong candidate for a mortgage loan and the other may be an average candidate who has faced challenges in their credit journey.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_3: Fannie Mae’s new credit score rule makes buying or refinancing a home easier for co-borrowers from dual-income households. Here is a breakdown of what this new change entails and how it can help couples acquire a mortgage loan.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_4: How Has Mortgage Loan Approval Worked In The Past?
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_5: As we previously mentioned, a high credit score is a major factor in determining mortgage loan eligibility. Your credit score is determined based on your past payment history and borrowing behavior. When applying for a mortgage, a credit score has a huge impact on an approval. Conventional loans typically require a FICO score of at least 620. The higher your score, the more likely you will be approved and the better your interest rate will be.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_6: Dual-income households have a better chance of getting approved for a mortgage loan if both the primary and secondary borrowers are strong applicants. This is challenging for partners who have completely different credit profiles which is very common.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_7: In the past, Fannie Mae required both co-borrowers to have a minimum credit score of 620 in order to move forward with a mortgage loan. For example, if two co-borrowers had scores of 690 and 580, they were not eligible to buy or refinance a home together since one of them did not meet the minimum credit score requirement of 620. In this case, the borrower with the higher credit score would more than likely have to apply as a single applicant which can pose challenges if they have a higher debt-to-income ratio or do not have a strong work history to back them up. Single borrowers must qualify for the mortgage loan based on their single income, which could negatively affect the outcome of approval.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_8: How Does The New Credit Rule Work and How Does it Benefit You?
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_9: As of September 18, 2021, Fannie Mae’s new credit score rule allows lenders to average the co-borrower’s FICO scores together to determine eligibility for a conventional loan.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_10: What does this mean for you? Using the same example of the two co-borrowers with credit scores of 690 and 580, if we were to evaluate their average credit score it would be 635. Where they may have struggled before, this new average score makes the co-borrowers eligible to buy or refinance a home.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_11: Combined income may allow two co-borrowers to qualify for a larger loan amount since together they can afford a higher monthly mortgage payment. With Fannie Mae’s new rule, co-borrowers have a better chance of final approval for a home loan based on their average combined credit score and both their incomes taken into consideration.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_12: Fannie Mae’s new credit rule can also help couples save money by refinancing their mortgage loan for a chance to receive lower interest rates on their current loan. Previous borrowers who were forced to apply as individual applicants can now refinance as dual-income households to lower their monthly mortgage payments and decrease interest fees.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_14: Here at ZoomLoans, we focus on choosing the best real estate loan options that will help you achieve your goals of purchasing or refinancing your home.
how_fannie_maes_new_credit_score.txt_15: Conventional loans follow lending rules set by Fannie Mae, offering mortgages with as little as 3% down. This new credit rule change has arrived just in time as mortgage rates are beginning to rise.

what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.head: What Are the Pros and Cons of Refinancing Your Home?
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_1: The Truth About Refinancing Your Mortgage
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_2: The financial market sometimes refers to a home mortgage as “good debt.” This is largely because unlike a credit card or personal loan, a mortgage can help you buy and own an asset that may increase in value as time goes on.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_3: A smart way to transform this implied “good” mortgage debt into an even better situation exists in what we call a mortgage refinance. However, is it really a good idea to refinance a mortgage?
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_4: If you are considering this financial option, there are many pros and cons of refinancing you must consider.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_5: The Truth About Refinancing Your Mortgage
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_6: Refinancing involves taking your mortgage loan and refinancing it into a new loan with entirely new terms. Homeowners commonly do this to obtain a lower mortgage payment, reduce interest rates, and ultimately save some money.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_7: Consequently, mortgage lenders may also charge fees as a part of a mortgage refinance. Because of these fees, you really must comprehensively understand every aspect that concerns the new loan. This can help you determine the accurate benefits that mortgage refinancing can offer you.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_8: The Pros and Cons of Refinancing Your Mortgage
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_10: Refinancing with a lower rate could help you pay less interest each month, as well as over the lifetime of the loan.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_11: If you possess mortgage insurance and refinance into a loan that doesn’t require it, this may mean you save money throughout the lifetime of the loan.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_12: Shortening loans terms can save money by enabling you to repay the note sooner.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_13: If you lengthen your loan’s term, monthly payments may remain lower and more affordable.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_14: In some scenarios, you can refinance from an adjustable rate mortgage into a fixed rate one. This way, you don’t need to worry about modifications to a higher rate or increased payments in the future.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_15: With enough equity in the property, you could obtain cash back from a refinance. This could help you pay down other debt, as well as make improvements to the home.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_17: Refinancing with a higher rate can impart more interest each month and throughout the life of the loan.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_18: If you refinance to a shorter term, this down lower your rates. However, this might also increase payment costs and interest as time goes on.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_19: You will need to pay closing costs for the new mortgage. This might equate to thousands of dollars out of pocket.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_20: If you plan on selling the property within the next few years, you may never recover your closing costs.
what_are_the_pros_and_cons_of_refinancin.txt_21: Refinancing requires spending an exorbitant amount of time researching lenders, loans, and gathering financial information.

what_veterans_should_know.head: What Veterans Should Know
what_veterans_should_know.txt_1: What Is the Difference Between an FHA Loan and a VA Loan?
what_veterans_should_know.txt_2: An FHA loan is a loan insured by the Federal Housing Administration. It is aimed at helping conventional loans because of their lower requirements.
what_veterans_should_know.txt_3: Like FHA loans, a VA loan is a government-backed loan funded through the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for active military and Veterans. It's appealing to first-time buyers because it requires zero money down and no mortgage insurance.

comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.head: Comparing FHA and Conventional Home Loans
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_1: When it comes to mortgages, you have a lot of options. Two of the most common are FHA and conventional loans.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_2: Though both can be great products to help you buy a home, each has its own unique pros and cons and one may be better tailored to your income level, credit score and homebuying goals -- so know the difference and which option may be a better fit for you.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_4: FHA loans and conventional loans have vastly different credit score thresholds. In addition, with the FHA loan, your credit score also affects the minimum down payment requirement.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_5: With the FHA loan, homebuyers whose credit score is 580 or higher may qualify for the lower 3.5 percent down payment option, while those with a credit score between 500 and 579 may still qualify, but need at least 10 percent down.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_6: Conventional credit requirements can vary by lender, but typically conventional loans require a credit score in the 620-640 range regardless of down payment. This higher threshold often excludes those with less-than-perfect credit and many first-time homebuyers.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_7: FHA vs. Conventional Loans: The Down Payment Requirements
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_8: As mentioned above, FHA loans allow as little as 3.5 percent down – or about $7,000 on a $200,000 home.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_9: Down payment requirements for conventional loans can vary by lender and other factors but a 5 percent minimum is common. That would mean a $10,000 down payment on a $200,000 property.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_10: If coming up with your down payment is difficult, both loan types allow you to use gift money toward your payment. However, with an FHA loan, your entire down payment can be from gift funds, while those using a conventional loan may need to put down a portion of their own funds before being able to include gift money. Talk with a lender for more details.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_11: Conventional and FHA Mortgage Insurance Costs
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_12: Conventional loans typically require private mortgage insurance unless borrowers can put down 20 percent. Costs for PMI can vary based on your credit score and other factors, but it can easily add $100 or more to your monthly payment. This expense typically ends once your loan-to-value ratio reaches 80 percent.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_13: Conversely, FHA loans require mortgage insurance no matter what -- even if you’re putting 20 percent down. FHA loans come with both a one-time upfront fee and annual mortgage insurance premium (which you’ll pay monthly, as part of your mortgage payment).
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_15: The upfront MIP, sometimes referred to as the FHA funding fee, is 1.75 percent of the loan amount. This fee is due at closing and is typically financed into the entire loan amount to reduce out of pocket costs.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_17: The annual MIP ranges from .45 percent to 1.05 percent depending on loan term, loan amount and down payment. However, for most FHA borrowers, the annual MIP is .85 percent of the loan amount.
comparing_fHA_and_conventional_home_loan.txt_18: The annual MIP can last for the life of the loan, or be removed after 11 years if the original down payment is 10% or more.

FHA_loan_refinancing_options.head: FHA Loan Refinancing Options
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_1: Refinancing can be an excellent way to lower your monthly payment, shorten your loan term, change loan products or even get cash from your home equity for remodeling, paying bills and more.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_2: For homeowners with FHA loans, there are several ways to approach a refinance, each with its own unique advantages and use cases. Just keep in mind refinancing may result in higher finance charges over the life of the loan.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_4: There are a number of ways to go about an FHA refinance. FHA homeowners can utilize any of the following options:
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_5: FHA Streamline refinance - This type of refinance is designed to lower your interest rate and, subsequently, your monthly payment. It’s called a “Streamline” because it’s a fast, efficient process designed to save time and money.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_6: FHA Cash-Out refinance - This allows you to turn home equity into cash, which you can then use to cover home projects or other expenses you may be facing.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_7: FHA simple refinance - The simple refinance lets you replace your existing FHA loan with a new one. It can be a new fixed-rate loan or an adjustable-rate one.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_8: 203(k) refinance - The 203(k) refinance is also called a “rehabilitation” loan. It’s ideal for buyers looking to renovate or rehabilitate a downtrodden property.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_9: The two most common types of FHA refinances are the Cash-Out and the Streamline.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_11: Many homeowners shy away from refinancing, for fear it’s too time-consuming and burdensome. The FHA Streamline refinance aims to refute that assumption, offering a quick, easy and hassle-free road to refinancing an existing FHA loan.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_13: The FHA Streamline refinance is meant to be a quick, painless process for existing FHA borrowers. The assumption is that because the homeowner has already passed the FHA’s stringent requirements once, they do not need to be as carefully vetted the second time around. This results in less paperwork, a shorter underwriting period and less focus on the borrower’s credit and financial documentation.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_14: Who Qualifies for the FHA Streamline
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_15: Homeowners who already have an FHA loan, are current on their payments and can see either a long-term or short-term net benefit by refinancing may qualify for this option.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_16: Lenders might require the existing FHA loan be at least 210 days old. Talk with lenders about their guidelines regarding what’s known as “seasoning.”
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_17: Benefits of the FHA Streamline Refinance
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_18: Less paperwork than other refinance options
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_19: No credit check in some cases
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_25: Depending on your situation, you may be able to get an FHA Streamline without an appraisal. Since appraisals come with a fee, this can save homeowners several hundred dollars.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_26: Homeowners can still choose to get an appraisal, and doing so qualifies you to include closing costs in your new loan amount. This would increase your monthly payment slightly but lower the upfront costs of your refinance.
FHA_loan_refinancing_options.txt_27: Homeowners who use the FHA Streamline refinance program also might be eligible for a refund on their initial MIP (mortgage insurance premium). The amount of this refund decreases every month after your initial loan closing.

faq.head: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.txt_2: FHA loans are backed by the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) and are popular among first-time homebuyers due to the program’s low down payment and relaxed credit requirements.
faq.txt_3: FHA loans are ideal for homebuyers without sufficient savings for a large down payment or those with less-than-perfect credit, lacking the ability to qualify for a conventional loan. FHA loans require a minimum credit score of at least 580 to take advantage of the program’s 3.5 percent down payment option. Those with scores below 580 may still qualify for FHA funding, but will need to put at least 10 percent down.
faq.txt_5: An assumable mortgage allows homebuyers to take over a seller’s mortgage, including the rate, repayment period, current principal balance and other loan terms. Currently only government backed loan options allow assumable mortgages - conventional loans are typically not assumable.
faq.txt_6: The primary advantage to assuming a mortgage is securing a lower interest rate rather than applying for a new loan when rates are higher. Often assuming an existing mortgage is less costly for the buyer than obtaining a new loan.
faq.txt_7: Buyers will still need to meet all of the lender and FHA’s requirements before assumption is permitted.

home.head: FHA Loan Tools and Resources
home.card_1_txt_1: The FHA payment calculator calculates an accurate FHA mortgage payment by accounting for the FHA guarantee fee, monthly FHA mortgage insurance, property taxes, and homeowner's insurance.
home.card_2_txt_1: The FHA Affordability Calculator will help you determine whether you can comfortably pay for the home you want to buy or refinance.

fhaCalculator.head: FHA Loan Calculator
fhaCalculator.txt_1: Our free FHA loan calculator estimates what your payments could be with an FHA loan. We include key features unique to the FHA loan, including the FHA’s upfront and annual Mortgage Insurance Premiums (MIP), to produce an accurate representation of your purchasing power with an FHA loan.
fhaCalculator.txt_6: Estimated based on current trends. Subject to change. Rates can vary.
fhaCalculator.txt_8: Property taxes are generally estimated to be 1.2% of the home's value, but may vary based on your location.
fhaCalculator.txt_10: Annual homeowners insurance is typically 0.35% of the homes value but can vary based on insurer.
fhaCalculator.txt_17: An FHA loan is a government-backed conforming loan insured by the Federal Housing Administration. FHA loans have lower credit and down payment requirements for qualified homebuyers. The minimum required down payment for an FHA loan is only 3.5%. The FHA mortgage calculator includes additional costs, including upfront monthly mortgage insurance (MIP) and annual premiums in the estimated monthly payment.

fhaCalculator.txt_20: Be sure to also check your that your loan is within the FHA loan limits. FHA loan limits in 2022 range from $420,680 to $970,800, depending on location.

fhaAffordabilityCalculator.head: How Much Can I Afford?
fhaAffordabilityCalculator.txt_1: Use the following calculator to help you determine an affordable monthly payment so that you know what you can afford before you make an offer on the home you want to purchase.
fhaAffordabilityCalculator.txt_13: The sum of the monthly mortgage, interest, tax and insurance payments must be equal or less than 50% of your gross (pre-taxes) monthly salary.
fhaAffordabilityCalculator.txt_14: DISCLAIMER: The figures above are based upon FHA's debt-to-income ratio which is a ratio of total monthly debt payments (housing expense, installment debts, and so on) to gross monthly income. The FHA has determined the acceptable ratio to be 50% and it is used as a guide. In circumstances where the ratio exceeds 50%, the FHA automatic underwriter can consider the ratio in conjunction with all other credit factors. Calculations by this tool are believed to be accurate, yet are not guaranteed. Further review is necessary to obtain an exact qualification.
